title: Paneer Recipe
description: This homemade paneer recipe uses just 2 ingredients to make soft and light Indian cheese great for adding to vegetarian curries and rice dishes.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Ingredients Dairy Recipes Cheese Recipes Paneer 4.5 (78) 59 Reviews 4 Photos This easy paneer recipe is great for vegetarians. You can add paneer to your favorite curry or dish. Homemade paneer is softer and lighter than the tofu-like consistency of paneer found in many Indian restaurants. Submitted by AMIBOULD Updated on June 27, 2023 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 4 4 Prep Time: 30 mins Cook Time: 20 mins Additional Time: 2 hrs Total Time: 2 hrs 50 mins Servings: 6 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 6 servings 1 gallon milk 1 quart buttermilk 1 cup canola oil for frying Directions Pour milk into a large pot and bring to a boil over medium heat; watch carefully to prevent milk from boiling over. When milk begins to boil, pour buttermilk into the pot in a steady stream, stirring constantly. The milk will separate into curds and water. Line a colander with cheesecloth. Pour milk mixture through the cheesecloth, reserving some of the strained liquid. Let milk mixture sit in the colander until curds are settled and dripping stops, about 2 hours. Transfer strained curds to a food processor. Process until smooth and mixture can be formed into a ball. Add some of the reserved liquid and process again if mixture is too dry. The consistency should resemble firm ricotta cheese. Turn cheese out onto a clean surface and knead until smooth. Form into a ball and wrap in plastic. Refrigerate until needed. To cook paneer, heat oil in a large, heavy skillet over medium-high heat. Cut paneer into bite-sized pieces. Fry in hot oil until very pale golden brown, about 1 minute. Drain on a paper towel-lined plate. I Made It Print 93 home cooks made it! Add Your Photo Photos of Paneer 01 of 04 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 04 Photo by  jm_kv 07/05/2010 03 of 04 Photo by  REBE424 11/28/2007 PERFECTION! This is the best way to make paneer - try this method before using one that uses lemon juice or vineager which alter the natural flavor. This comes out creamy and delicious. I added salt the curds and omitted the food processor step. 1 You’ll Also Love Paneer (Cottage Cheese) 2 Ratings Sicilian Homemade Ricotta Cheese 73 Ratings Quick Indian Vegetarian Cottage Cheese Breakfast 3 Ratings Easy Garam Masala 276 Ratings Mild Curry Powder 52 Ratings Raita Sauce 1 Rating Rasgullas 5 Ratings Green Chutney 52 Ratings Potato Chapati Bread 6 Ratings Gulab Jamun or Kala Jam (Waffle Balls) 4 Ratings Besan Laddu 6 Ratings Indian Vegetarian Curried Cauliflower 4 Ratings Best Homemade Paneer 3 Ratings Navratan Korma 142 Ratings Indian Vegetable Bhaji 58 Ratings Besan (Gram Flour) Halwa 19 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: AMIBOULD
instructions: Pour milk into a large pot and bring to a boil over medium heat; watch carefully to prevent milk from boiling over. When milk begins to boil, pour buttermilk into the pot in a steady stream, stirring constantly. The milk will separate into curds and water.;Line a colander with cheesecloth. Pour milk mixture through the cheesecloth, reserving some of the strained liquid. Let milk mixture sit in the colander until curds are settled and dripping stops, about 2 hours.;Transfer strained curds to a food processor. Process until smooth and mixture can be formed into a ball. Add some of the reserved liquid and process again if mixture is too dry. The consistency should resemble firm ricotta cheese.;Turn cheese out onto a clean surface and knead until smooth. Form into a ball and wrap in plastic. Refrigerate until needed.;To cook paneer, heat oil in a large, heavy skillet over medium-high heat. Cut paneer into bite-sized pieces. Fry in hot oil until very pale golden brown, about 1 minute. Drain on a paper towel-lined plate.
